questions.text: In Greek mythology, who is the king of the gods?
questions.explanation: Zeus is the king of the Olympian gods, ruling from Mount Olympus.

questions.text: What is the name of Thor's hammer in Norse mythology?
questions.explanation: Mjolnir is Thor's legendary hammer, forged by the dwarves Sindri and Brokkr.

questions.text: Which Egyptian god has the head of a jackal?
questions.explanation: Anubis, the god of mummification and the afterlife, is depicted with a jackal head.

questions.text: In Roman mythology, who is the equivalent of the Greek goddess Aphrodite?
questions.explanation: Venus is the Roman goddess of love and beauty, equivalent to the Greek Aphrodite.

questions.text: What creature in Greek mythology has the body of a lion, wings of an eagle, and the head of a human?
questions.explanation: The Sphinx has a human head and a lion's body, and in Greek myth posed riddles to travelers near Thebes.

questions.text: Who is the Norse god of mischief and trickery?
questions.explanation: Loki is the trickster god in Norse mythology, known for shapeshifting and causing chaos among the gods.

questions.text: In Hindu mythology, who is the preserver god in the Trimurti?
questions.explanation: Vishnu is the preserver in the Hindu Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Shiva the destroyer.

questions.text: What is the name of the Greek hero who slew Medusa?
questions.explanation: Perseus beheaded the Gorgon Medusa using a mirrored shield to avoid her petrifying gaze.

questions.text: In Japanese mythology, what is the sun goddess called?
questions.explanation: Amaterasu is the sun goddess and one of the principal deities in Japanese Shinto mythology.

questions.text: Which mythical creature is reborn from its own ashes?
questions.explanation: The Phoenix is a mythical bird that cyclically regenerates by bursting into flames and rising from its ashes.

questions.text: Who wrote the epic poem 'The Iliad'?
questions.explanation: Homer is the ancient Greek poet traditionally credited with composing The Iliad and The Odyssey.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what is the name of the great world tree?
questions.explanation: Yggdrasil is the immense ash tree that connects the nine worlds in Norse cosmology.

questions.text: Which Greek god is associated with the forge and metalworking?
questions.explanation: Hephaestus is the Greek god of fire, metalworking, and the forge, who crafted weapons for the gods.

questions.text: What is the Egyptian Book of the Dead primarily about?

options.B: Spells to guide the deceased through the afterlife

questions.explanation: The Book of the Dead is a collection of funerary texts with spells to help the deceased navigate the underworld.

questions.text: In Celtic mythology, what is the Otherworld commonly called?
questions.explanation: Tir na nOg, meaning 'Land of the Young,' is the Celtic Otherworld of eternal youth and beauty.

questions.text: Who is the Hindu god with an elephant head?
questions.explanation: Ganesha is the elephant-headed god of beginnings, wisdom, and the remover of obstacles.

questions.text: In Greek mythology, who flew too close to the sun with wax wings?
questions.explanation: Icarus ignored his father Daedalus's warning and flew too close to the sun, melting his wax wings.

questions.text: What is the name of Odin's eight-legged horse in Norse mythology?
questions.explanation: Sleipnir is Odin's eight-legged steed, described as the best of all horses in Norse mythology.

questions.text: Which Roman god is equivalent to the Greek god Ares?
questions.explanation: Mars is the Roman god of war, equivalent to the Greek god Ares.

questions.text: In the Japanese creation myth, who are the divine couple that created the islands of Japan?
questions.explanation: Izanagi and Izanami are the primordial divine couple who created the Japanese archipelago.

questions.text: What did Prometheus steal from the gods to give to humanity?
questions.explanation: Prometheus stole fire from the gods and gave it to humanity, for which Zeus punished him severely.

questions.text: In Egyptian mythology, who is the god of the sun?
questions.explanation: Ra is the Egyptian sun god who travels across the sky in his solar barque each day.

questions.text: How many labors did Heracles have to complete?
questions.explanation: Heracles was tasked with completing 12 labors as penance, assigned by King Eurystheus.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what event marks the end of the world?
questions.explanation: Ragnarok is the prophesied series of events including a great battle that results in the death of major gods and the submersion of the world.

questions.text: Which mythical creature has the head and wings of an eagle and the body of a lion?
questions.explanation: A Griffin (or Gryphon) combines the eagle's head, wings, and talons with the body of a lion.

questions.text: Who is the Greek goddess of wisdom and warfare strategy?
questions.explanation: Athena is the goddess of wisdom, strategic warfare, and crafts, born from the head of Zeus.

questions.text: In Hindu mythology, what is the name of the monkey god who aided Rama?
questions.explanation: Hanuman is the monkey god known for his devotion to Lord Rama and his role in the Ramayana.

questions.text: What is the Minotaur trapped inside in Greek mythology?
questions.explanation: The Minotaur was confined in the Labyrinth beneath Crete, designed by the architect Daedalus.

questions.text: Which Norse god sacrificed his hand to bind the wolf Fenrir?
questions.explanation: Tyr placed his hand in Fenrir's mouth as a pledge of good faith while the wolf was bound, losing it when Fenrir realized the trick.

questions.text: In Egyptian mythology, which goddess is often depicted with a throne on her head?
questions.explanation: Isis, the goddess of magic and motherhood, is frequently depicted with a throne hieroglyph on her head.

questions.text: What is the name of the ferryman who carries souls across the River Styx?
questions.explanation: Charon is the ferryman of the dead, transporting souls across the rivers of the underworld.

questions.text: In Japanese mythology, what creature is a shapeshifting fox?
questions.explanation: Kitsune are intelligent foxes in Japanese folklore that gain additional tails and shapeshifting abilities as they age.

questions.text: Who killed the Nemean Lion as his first labor?
questions.explanation: Heracles strangled the Nemean Lion with his bare hands as the first of his twelve labors.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, who guards the rainbow bridge Bifrost?
questions.explanation: Heimdall is the watchman of the gods who guards Bifrost, the rainbow bridge connecting Asgard to Midgard.

questions.text: What was Achilles' only vulnerable spot?
questions.explanation: Achilles' mother Thetis dipped him in the River Styx, holding him by his heel, which remained vulnerable.

questions.text: Which Hindu epic tells the story of Prince Rama's quest to rescue his wife Sita?
questions.explanation: The Ramayana is the ancient Sanskrit epic narrating Rama's journey to rescue Sita from the demon king Ravana.

questions.text: In Greek mythology, what did Pandora release when she opened her box?
questions.explanation: Pandora's box (originally a jar) released all the evils and misfortunes into the world, leaving only Hope inside.

questions.text: Which Celtic hero is known for his 'warp spasm' battle frenzy?
questions.explanation: Cu Chulainn, the Hound of Ulster, was famous for his riastrad (warp spasm), a terrifying battle transformation.

questions.text: What three-headed dog guards the entrance to the Greek underworld?
questions.explanation: Cerberus is the three-headed hound that guards the gates of the underworld, preventing the dead from leaving.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what do fallen warriors in Valhalla do each day?

options.B: Fight and are resurrected to feast at night

questions.explanation: The Einherjar fight each day and are healed each evening to feast in the great hall of Valhalla.

questions.text: Which Egyptian god was murdered by his brother Set and later became lord of the underworld?
questions.explanation: Osiris was killed by his brother Set and resurrected by Isis, after which he became ruler of the underworld.

questions.text: What is the name of the legendary sword King Arthur pulled from a stone?
questions.explanation: Excalibur is the legendary sword associated with King Arthur. In some versions it is the sword in the stone; in others it is given by the Lady of the Lake.

questions.text: In Greek mythology, who turned everything he touched into gold?
questions.explanation: King Midas was granted the golden touch by Dionysus, which turned everything he touched into gold.

questions.text: What is the name of the Japanese storm god and brother of Amaterasu?
questions.explanation: Susanoo is the storm god in Japanese mythology and the brother of Amaterasu and Tsukuyomi.

questions.text: In the Mahabharata, what divine discourse does Krishna give to Arjuna on the battlefield?
questions.explanation: The Bhagavad Gita is the sacred dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna set within the Mahabharata.

questions.text: Which Greek Titan holds up the sky?
questions.explanation: Atlas was condemned by Zeus to hold up the celestial heavens for eternity as punishment after the Titanomachy.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what is the name of the great serpent that encircles the world?
questions.explanation: Jormungandr, also called the Midgard Serpent, is so large it encircles the entire world and grasps its own tail.

questions.text: Who is the Roman goddess of the hunt, equivalent to the Greek Artemis?
questions.explanation: Diana is the Roman goddess of the hunt, the moon, and nature, equivalent to the Greek goddess Artemis.

questions.text: What creature did Bellerophon ride to defeat the Chimera?
questions.explanation: Bellerophon tamed and rode the winged horse Pegasus to defeat the fire-breathing Chimera.

questions.text: In Egyptian mythology, what must the heart of the deceased be weighed against in the Hall of Ma'at?
questions.explanation: The heart of the deceased is weighed against the feather of Ma'at (truth). If heavier, the heart is devoured by Ammit.

questions.text: What is the name of the Celtic cauldron that could restore dead warriors to life?
questions.explanation: The Cauldron of Rebirth (Pair Dadeni) from the Mabinogion could bring dead soldiers back to life.

questions.text: Which Greek hero sailed with the Argonauts to find the Golden Fleece?
questions.explanation: Jason led the Argonauts on their voyage aboard the Argo to retrieve the Golden Fleece from Colchis.

questions.text: In Hindu mythology, what is the vehicle (vahana) of Lord Vishnu?
questions.explanation: Garuda, the divine eagle, serves as the mount of Lord Vishnu.

questions.text: What is the name of Odysseus's wife, who waited faithfully for his return?
questions.explanation: Penelope waited twenty years for Odysseus, fending off suitors by weaving and unraveling a shroud each night.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, who are the female figures that choose which warriors die in battle and go to Valhalla?
questions.explanation: The Valkyries are Odin's choosers of the slain, selecting worthy warriors to join the Einherjar in Valhalla.

questions.text: Which mythological hero is famous for his journey home described in 'The Odyssey'?
questions.explanation: The Odyssey tells the story of Odysseus's ten-year journey home to Ithaca after the Trojan War.

questions.text: In Japanese folklore, what is a Tanuki known for?
questions.explanation: Tanuki are raccoon dogs in Japanese folklore known for their shapeshifting abilities and mischievous nature.

questions.text: What was the punishment of Sisyphus in the Greek underworld?

options.A: Being chained to a rock while an eagle ate his liver
options.B: Standing in water that receded when he tried to drink
options.C: Rolling a boulder up a hill only for it to roll back down forever

questions.explanation: Sisyphus was condemned to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity, only for it to roll back down each time.

questions.text: Which Hindu deity is known as the Destroyer and performs the cosmic dance of Tandava?
questions.explanation: Shiva is the destroyer in the Trimurti and performs the Tandava, the cosmic dance of creation and destruction.

questions.text: In Greek mythology, who was the first woman, created by the gods as a punishment for humanity?
questions.explanation: Pandora was the first woman, crafted by Hephaestus on Zeus's orders as retribution for Prometheus stealing fire.

questions.text: What is the name of the Norse realm of the dead, ruled by Hel?
questions.explanation: Helheim is the realm of the dead in Norse mythology, presided over by the goddess Hel, daughter of Loki.

questions.text: Which Egyptian goddess takes the form of a cat?
questions.explanation: Bastet is the Egyptian goddess of home, fertility, and cats, often depicted as a cat or a woman with a cat's head.

questions.text: In the legend of Robin Hood, where does his band of outlaws live?
questions.explanation: Robin Hood and his Merry Men make their home in Sherwood Forest in Nottinghamshire.

questions.text: Who is the Greek god of the sea?
questions.explanation: Poseidon is the Greek god of the sea, earthquakes, and horses, and brother of Zeus and Hades.

questions.text: In Chinese mythology, what creature is the dragon traditionally associated with?
questions.explanation: In Chinese mythology, dragons are benevolent symbols of power, strength, and good fortune, closely associated with water and rain.

questions.text: What is the Chimera in Greek mythology?

options.B: A creature with a lion's head, goat's body, and serpent's tail

questions.explanation: The Chimera is a fire-breathing hybrid with the head of a lion, body of a goat, and tail of a serpent.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what did Odin sacrifice to gain wisdom from the Well of Mimir?
questions.explanation: Odin sacrificed one of his eyes to drink from the Well of Mimir and gain cosmic wisdom.

questions.text: Which Greek hero is known for his cleverness and the strategy of the Trojan Horse?
questions.explanation: Odysseus devised the strategy of the Trojan Horse, which led to the fall of Troy.

questions.text: In Hindu mythology, what are the avatars of Vishnu?
questions.explanation: Avatars are Vishnu's earthly incarnations, including Rama, Krishna, and others, who descend to restore cosmic order.

questions.text: What is the name of the legendary city that sank beneath the ocean?
questions.explanation: Atlantis is the legendary island civilization described by Plato that supposedly sank into the sea.

questions.text: In Egyptian mythology, which god has the head of an ibis bird?
questions.explanation: Thoth, the god of writing, wisdom, and magic, is depicted with the head of an ibis.

questions.text: Who is the leader of the Wild Hunt in various European mythologies?
questions.explanation: Odin (or Wodan) is most commonly identified as the leader of the Wild Hunt in Norse and Germanic traditions.

questions.text: In Greek mythology, what type of creature is a centaur?
questions.explanation: A centaur has the upper body of a human and the lower body of a horse.

questions.text: What is the name of the sword wielded by the Norse hero Sigurd to slay the dragon Fafnir?
questions.explanation: Gram is the legendary sword reforged from its broken pieces that Sigurd used to kill the dragon Fafnir.

questions.text: In Japanese mythology, what is a Tengu?

options.B: A mountain spirit with a long nose or bird-like features

questions.explanation: Tengu are supernatural mountain spirits often depicted with long noses or bird-like features, associated with martial arts.

questions.text: Who is the mother of the Greek god Apollo?
questions.explanation: Leto is the Titaness mother of the twins Apollo and Artemis, fathered by Zeus.

questions.text: In Celtic mythology, who are the Tuatha De Danann?

options.B: A supernatural race of gods and heroes

questions.explanation: The Tuatha De Danann are the supernatural race of Irish mythology, often regarded as gods or fairy folk.

questions.text: What did the Greek hero Theseus use to find his way out of the Labyrinth?
questions.explanation: Ariadne gave Theseus a ball of thread (clew) to unwind as he entered so he could retrace his steps after slaying the Minotaur.

questions.text: In Norse mythology, what are the Norns responsible for?

options.B: Weaving the fates of gods and men

questions.explanation: The Norns (Urd, Verdandi, and Skuld) are the three beings who control destiny by weaving the threads of fate at the base of Yggdrasil.

questions.text: Which Roman poet wrote 'The Aeneid', telling the story of the Trojan hero Aeneas?
questions.explanation: Virgil (Publius Vergilius Maro) wrote The Aeneid, an epic poem about Aeneas's journey from Troy to Italy.
